bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James F. Minor, April 7, 1948

div1.p: Hench informs Minor that he will be pleased to give a talk on Walter Reed for the Albemarle County Historical Society. He discusses details related to arrangements and scheduling.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James F. Minor, April 7, 1948
div1.opener:
April 7, 1948
Mr. James F. Minor, President
Albemarle County Historical Society
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Mr. Minor:
div1.p:
I shall be pleased to accept the invitation of the Albemarle
County Historical Society to give a talk on Walter Reed and the Conquest
of Yellow Fever, Monday evening, May 10.

I will use standard-size lantern slides and would like to
have a reading stand and lamp and of course a porter. That is all the
preparation that is necessary. May I assure you that my talk is fitted
for the layman and is not in any way scientific or medical. I shall
merely discuss the human interest side of the dramatic conquest of yellow
fever as accomplished by Major Reed and his associates.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P.S.: I am trying to arrange other eastern appointments about this time. I am
having a committee meeting at the Waldorf, New York City, on Sunday, May 9
and am speaking in Washington on May 12 before the International Congress on May
12. I have just received a latter from the director of the Congress to set up an
exhibit on Walter Reed and they want the exhibit set up by 8o'clock Monday morning
May 10. According to my present plans, this is utterly impossible as part of the
exhibit is now on loan to the University of Virginia and I had planned to pick it
up there on the 10th and set it up in Washington on the 11th. I did not ask to
put up this exhibit, they requested it. But if tey get too insistant, is there
any possibility that your meeting might be held Saturday evening, May 8? My own
reaction is to leave the dates just as they are. I am not inclined to quibble and
imagine that Saturday evening would be a very bad time for the meeting of your County
Historical Society. If worse comes to worse, I will just have to take my chances
and perhaps ask my former secretary, Miss Schnurr, who now lives in Washington,
to go down to the University, pick the material up and set it up for me in
Washington some time Sunday, May 9.
